name: Jade Emperor's Palace
shortDescription: Supreme celestial palace where the Jade Emperor rules the heavenly bureaucracy
fullDescription: The Jade Emperor's Palace (ç‰çš‡å®®, YÃ¹huÃ¡ng GÅng) is the supreme seat of power in the Chinese celestial realm, located in the highest heaven. From this magnificent palace of jade and gold, the Jade Emperor (Yuhuang Dadi) governs the cosmos through an elaborate heavenly bureaucracy mirroring the earthly imperial administration. The palace hosts the Peach Banquet of Immortality, celestial court sessions where gods report their duties, and serves as the ultimate authority over heaven, earth, and underworld. It is the center of cosmic order and divine governance.

properties.name: Structure
properties.value: Palace of jade and gold with countless halls and chambers

properties.name: Notable Events
properties.value: Peach Banquet, celestial court sessions, divine appointments

mythologyContexts.usage: Center of celestial governance and cosmic order. Site of divine assemblies, the Peach Banquet, and bureaucratic administration of the universe. Destination for petitions from gods, immortals, and worthy mortals

rituals.name: Peach Banquet of Immortality
rituals.description: Every 3,000 years, the Jade Emperor hosts a grand feast with Xi Wangmu's peaches of immortality

rituals.name: Havoc in Heaven
rituals.description: Sun Wukong rebelled against the celestial order, fighting his way through the palace

rituals.name: Celestial Audience
rituals.description: Gods and immortals attend court to report on their domains and receive imperial decrees

rituals.name: Divine Appointments
rituals.description: The Jade Emperor assigns gods to govern aspects of nature and human affairs

textReferences.context: Sun Wukong's rebellion and the Havoc in Heaven at the Jade Emperor's palace
Celestial court proceedings and divine interventions
Daoist text describing the Jade Emperor's authority and palace

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Jade Emperor's Palace represents the perfected cosmic order - a universe governed by merit, hierarchy, and bureaucratic efficiency. The jade material symbolizes supreme virtue and incorruptibility. The palace's location in the highest heaven reflects the Confucian ideal of hierarchical harmony. Its bureaucratic structure mirrors Chinese imperial government, suggesting divine mandate for earthly rulership.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The concept of a heavenly bureaucracy profoundly influenced Chinese political philosophy, religious practice, and cultural imagination. The Jade Emperor's palace appears in countless stories, operas, and artworks. Temple worship of the Jade Emperor and celestial officials reflects the folk religious adaptation of this cosmic governmental system.

etymology.components: ç‰ (jade, precious) + çš‡ (august, emperor) + æ®¿ (palace hall, main building)

originPoint.description: Celestial palace above the 33 heavens; supreme point of cosmic bureaucracy
originPoint.mythicalLocation: Apex of heaven, above all celestial realms

firstAttestation.description: Jade Emperor cult formalized in Song dynasty; palace concept fully developed in Journey to the West (1592)

temporal.philosophicalContext: Daoist celestial bureaucracy; Jade Emperor as supreme deity formalized under Song imperial patronage
